title: 111_hr2984
content:
The "United States Mariner and Vessel Protection Act of 2009" aims to defend US-flag vessels against piracy and uphold their right to self-defense. It allows the use of Maritime Safety and Security Teams to protect these vessels in international waters. Section 70106 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow the Commandant of the Coast Guard to deploy a maritime safety and security team for up to six months to combat piracy in international waters. The Commandant must notify Congress within 10 days of such deployment. The new section added to Chapter 701 of title 46, United States Code, grants the Secretary authority to establish regulations for the use of force, including lethal force, in defense against piracy. It also limits liability for owners, operators, masters, and individuals involved in such actions. The new section in Chapter 701 of title 46, US Code allows the Secretary to set rules for using force against piracy. It limits liability for individuals using authorized force unless grossly negligent or engaging in willful misconduct. The section defines a vessel as one with a certificate of inspection operating in high-risk waters. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates must issue regulations within specified deadlines regarding the use of force and training individuals with licenses or merchant mariner documents in firearms use aboard vessels. SEC. 5. AGREEMENTS.

The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates will work with the International Maritime Organization to establish agreements promoting coordinated action against piracy and ensuring liability limitations for vessels under the jurisdiction of nations.
